title: 6 Ways to Quickly Zoom Out on a Mac

steps.title: Click the Apple menu .
steps.content: Click the Apple menu . If you want to use your keyboard to zoom in or out on the entire screen (rather than a single window), use this method to set up Accessibility keyboard shortcuts. Start by clicking the Apple menu at the top-left corner of the screen. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click System Settings on the menu.
steps.content: Click System Settings on the menu. If you’re using an earlier version of macOS, this might be called System Preferences instead.

steps.title: Click the Accessibility icon.
steps.content: Click the Accessibility icon. It's the blue-and-white person icon in the left-hand menu bar. In older versions of macOS, you might need to look for this icon in the main System Preferences window instead.

steps.title: Click the Zoom menu.
steps.content: Click the Zoom menu. It’s under the Vision header in the main Accessibility menu.

steps.title: Check the box next to "Use keyboard shortcuts to zoom".
steps.content: Check the box next to "Use keyboard shortcuts to zoom". This will enable you to use a quick keyboard shortcut to zoom in and out on your entire screen.

steps.title: Press ⌥ Option+⌘ Command+8 to quickly zoom in or out.
steps.content: Press ⌥ Option + ⌘ Command + 8 to quickly zoom in or out. This is an all-purpose keyboard shortcut that will switch you from one zoom mode to the other. If you’re zoomed in, press Option-Command-8 to zoom out, and vice versa. If you’re zoomed really far in, this command will instantly zoom you all the way out to your screen’s normal resolution.

steps.title: Press ⌥ Option+⌘ Command+= to zoom in.
steps.content: Press ⌥ Option + ⌘ Command + = to zoom in. This enlarges the entire screen. Continue pressing this keyboard shortcut to zoom in as far as you'd like to go. Unlike the Option-Command-8 keyboard combo, this shortcut allows you to keep zooming in closer and closer.

steps.title: Press ⌥ Option+⌘ Command+- to zoom out.
steps.content: Press ⌥ Option + ⌘ Command + - to zoom out. This zooms the entire screen back out. As with zooming in, you can continue pressing this shortcut to zoom out as far as necessary. Unlike the Option-Command-8 command, this command will zoom you out in increments. So, if you zoomed in multiple times for a really close-up view, you’d have to use this command repeatedly to return to default resolution.

steps.title: Open System Settings.
steps.content: Open System Settings. If you prefer using your mouse or trackpad to zoom in on your screen, you can set this up using the Accessibility settings. Click the Apple menu at the top of your screen, then select System Settings . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click Accessibility.
steps.content: Click Accessibility . It’s located in the left-hand menu bar.

steps.title: Click Zoom.
steps.content: Click Zoom . You’ll see this in the right-hand panel under the Vision header.

steps.title: Toggle on Use trackpad gesture to zoom.
steps.content: Toggle on Use trackpad gesture to zoom . You can have this option toggled on at the same time as other zoom methods, like Use keyboard shortcuts to zoom .

steps.title: Double-tap your trackpad with three fingers to zoom in or out.
steps.content: Double-tap your trackpad with three fingers to zoom in or out. This is a simple toggle method. Performing the gesture once will zoom in. Performing it again will zoom you out again.

steps.title: Double tap and drag to change your zoom level.
steps.content: Double tap and drag to change your zoom level. To control how much you zoom in or out, use a slightly modified version of the gesture. Double tap with three fingers to zoom in, and then, with your fingers still on the trackpad, drag them up or down to change the amount of zoom. If you double tap and drag to zoom in, double tapping again will instantly zoom you all the way back out.

steps.title: Enable the Scroll Gesture with Modifier Keys option.
steps.content: Enable the Scroll Gesture with Modifier Keys option. If you're using a mouse that has a physical scroll wheel, a mouse with a multi-touch surface (such as the Apple Magic Mouse), or a laptop trackpad, you can use it to zoom and out in any window by associating a "modifier" key. This makes it so you can press a key (such as Command) while you scroll up or down on the wheel/surface to zoom. Here's how to enable this: Click the Apple menu and select System Settings . Click the Accessibility icon (the blue-and-white person icon). Click Zoom in the right panel. Toggle the switch next to "Use scroll gesture with modifier keys to zoom." Select a modifier key, such as Control or Command . Note that you can use this method alongside other zoom options, like using a keyboard shortcut or a trackpad gesture.

steps.title: Press the modifier key when you're ready to zoom in or out.
steps.content: Press the modifier key when you're ready to zoom in or out. For example, if you selected the Control key, press and hold it down now.

steps.title: Scroll upward on the mouse wheel to zoom in.
steps.content: Scroll upward on the mouse wheel to zoom in. If you're using a Magic Mouse or laptop trackpad, use two fingers to swipe upward on the surface instead.

steps.title: Scroll downward on the mouse wheel to zoom out.
steps.content: Scroll downward on the mouse wheel to zoom out. Using a Magic Mouse or trackpad, use two fingers to swipe downward instead.

steps.title: Navigate to Zoom in System Settings.
steps.content: Navigate to Zoom in System Settings. With any of the zoom options in accessibility, you can modify your zoom style depending on your preferences. Go to Apple menu > System Settings > Accessibility > Zoom to adjust these settings. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Select a zoom style from the dropdown menu.
steps.content: Select a zoom style from the dropdown menu. Next to the Zoom style header, click the dropdown menu. You can choose from Full Screen, Split Screen, or Picture-in-Picture. Full screen will show your entire screen zoomed in or out, while the other options will use a split screen or a smaller window to show the screen both zoomed in and at regular resolution. Click the Size and Location button to modify the appearance of your split screen or picture-in-picture zoom display. If you have Full Screen selected, you can click Choose Display… to show the zoomed in screen on a secondary monitor.

steps.title: Click Advanced… for more options.
steps.content: Click Advanced… for more options. For even more control over your Mac’s zoom behavior, click the Advanced… button at the bottom right corner of the window. When you’re done making any adjustments, click OK . You can always return to this menu and click Restore shortcuts and modifiers to reset your changes. The Advanced menu allows you to modify things like: How zoomed images move when you’re interacting with your screen. The minimum and maximum zoom factors for rapid zoom actions. Which keyboard shortcuts you use to control various zoom actions (like toggling between full screen and picture-in-picture). How quickly the screen image moves when you’re focusing on a particular item.

steps.title: Open the window you want to zoom in.
steps.content: Open the window you want to zoom in. If you just want to zoom in or out in a single application window, such as Safari or Pages, you can use a quick keyboard shortcut on any Mac without having to configure special settings.

steps.title: Press ⌘ Command++ to zoom in.
steps.content: Press ⌘ Command + + to zoom in. Holding these keys down at the same time enlarges the content of the window so you can get a better look. Continue pressing the + (plus) key to zoom in as far as you need to. This won’t work in all apps (e.g., Microsoft Word). If these keyboard shortcuts are already associated with a different function in the app you’re using, you’ll have to use another method.

steps.title: Press ⌘ Command+- to zoom out.
steps.content: Press ⌘ Command + - to zoom out. This zooms out the open window. As with zooming in, keep pressing the - (minus) key to zoom out as much as necessary.

steps.title: Move the cursor to the desired position.
steps.content: Move the cursor to the desired position. If you're using your laptop's trackpad or an external Magic Trackpad, you can use it to zoom in or out with a quick finger gesture. Start by moving the cursor to the location where you want to zoom out. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Place two fingers together on the trackpad.
steps.content: Place two fingers together on the trackpad. Do this right over the area where you want to zoom in or out.

steps.title: Move your two fingers apart to zoom in.
steps.content: Move your two fingers apart to zoom in. This motion is sort of a reverse-pinch. You can repeat the gesture to zoom in closer if you wish.

steps.title: Pinch two fingers together on the trackpad to zoom out.
steps.content: Pinch two fingers together on the trackpad to zoom out. Like with zooming in, you can repeat the pinch gesture to zoom out as far as you need to go.

steps.title: Double-tap in certain apps to smart zoom.
steps.content: Double-tap in certain apps to smart zoom. If you’re using a web browser or a PDF viewer, you can zoom in or out by double-tapping your trackpad with two fingers. Place your cursor over the part of the page where you want to zoom in, then double tap with both fingers. Double tap again to zoom out.
